items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences
items.body:
Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

```
py/tests/test_constraint.py:31
  /root/checked_repos/kiwi/py/tests/test_constraint.py:31: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \*
    constraint_format = '1 \* foo \+ 1 %s 0 | strength = 1.001e\+[0]+9' % op
```

items.title: Wheel support for linux aarch64
items.body:
**Summary**
Installing kiwisolver on aarch64 via pip using command "pip3 install kiwisolver" tries to build wheel from source code

**Problem description**
kiwisolver doesn't have wheel for aarch64 on PyPI repository. So, while installing kiwisolver via pip on aarch64, pip builds wheel for same resulting in it takes more time to install kiwisolver. Making wheel available for aarch64 will benefit aarch64 users by minimizing kiwisolver installation time.

**Expected Output**
Pip should be able to download kiwisolver wheel from PyPI repository rather than building it from source code.

@kiwisolver-team, please let me know if I can help you building wheel/uploading to PyPI repository. I am curious to make kiwisolver wheel available for aarch64. It will be a great opportunity for me to work with you.

items.title: install: cannot change permissions of ‘/usr/bin’: Operation not permitted
items.body:
The install step for the `tools` target is ignoring `--prefix` and going to `/usr`. This fails when installing into a Python that is not located there. Also while `/usr` is a fine default prefix, `usr` should not always be part of the prefix.

### The error:
```bash
install: cannot change permissions of ‘/usr/bin’: Operation not permitted
make[4]: *** [Makefile:17: install] Error 1
make[3]: *** [Makefile:45: install] Error 2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 221, in <module>
    setup(**config)
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/site-packages/setuptools/__init__.py", line 145, in setup
    return distutils.core.setup(**attrs)
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/distutils/core.py", line 148, in setup
    dist.run_commands()
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/distutils/dist.py", line 966, in run_commands
    self.run_command(cmd)
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/distutils/dist.py", line 985, in run_command
    cmd_obj.run()
  File "setup.py", line 170, in run
    subprocess.check_output(command).decode(),
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/subprocess.py", line 395, in check_output
    **kwargs).stdout
  File "/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/subprocess.py", line 487, in run
    output=stdout, stderr=stderr)
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['make', 'python_version=3', 'tools', 'install']' returned non-zero exit status 2.
```

### how to reproduce:
```bash
env CC=/usr/lib64/ccache/cc CXX=/usr/lib64/ccache/c++ \
    CPPFLAGS="-I/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/include" CFLAGS="-I/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/include  -O3 -march=native -mtune=native -DNDEBUG" \
    CXXFLAGS="-I/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/include  -O3 -march=native -mtune=native -DNDEBUG" \
    LDFLAGS="-L//home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib -L/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib64" \
    LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/:/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib64/: \
    DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/:/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib64/: \
    PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/pkgconfig:/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib64/pkgconfig: \
    PATH=.:/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/bin/:/usr/libexec/python3-sphinx:/usr/lib64/qt-3.3/bin:/usr/share/Modules/bin:/usr/lib64/ccache:/usr/local/bin:/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/home/bloring/.local/bin:/home/bloring/bin \
    PYTHONHOME=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install \
    MPLBACKEND=Agg \
    PYTHONPATH=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib:/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/lib/python3.7/site-packages/  \
    /home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install/bin/python3 setup.py build install --prefix=/home/bloring/work/teca/TECA_superbuild/install
```
we are building and installing a full stack of all of our project's dependencies. we install everything in arbitarry location specified by the user. environment variables setup the environment (as shown here). we are installing kiwi because it is a dependence of matplotlib.

### The problem
It seems that the command line that make's the target `tools`, doesn't override the variable `buildroot`. 

from top level Makefile
```bash
 21 .PHONY: tools
 22 tools:
 23     # apart from all python source we need to compile the
 24     # C tools. see setup.py for details when this target is
 25     # called
 26     ${MAKE} -C tools all
```
I think you could pass `buildroot=${buildroot}` on line 26?

Also, it looks weird to me that you are installing things to `${buildroot}/usr`.  From `tools/Makefile`
```bash
 16 install:
 17     install -d -m 755 ${buildroot}usr/bin
 18     install -m 755 $(PRGS) ${buildroot}usr/bin 
```
It is unusual to force `usr` into the install prefix. It will probably cause us problems even if the install succeeded. The more standard way would be to put stuff in `${buildroot}/bin`  and `${buildroot}/lib`, and make `buildroot` default to `/usr/` instead of hard coding `usr` into all the paths.

Hi,

when we packaged kiwisolver with conda we discovered that the package has a dependency to `setuptools`.

Is this dependency really required for kiwisolver to run? I cannot see any use of the package anywhere in the source code.

items.title: "ImportError: DLL load failed" on fresh Windows 10 installation
items.body:
I was trying to import matplotlib (which uses kiwisolver) and it failed with `ImportError: DLL load failed` and it turned out it was kiwisolver which actually failed to import.

The problem was solved by installing Microsoft Visual C++ redistributable 2015. Some dependencies (maybe fore precompiled binaries) must have been missing on the fresh/clean install of Windows 10.

See also: 
https://stackoverflow.com/a/38350913/4993453
https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/14303

items.title: MacOSX: avoid libstdc++ vs libc++ error
items.body: One option would be to pass -stdlib=libc++ as an option to the compiler through setuptools. It is probably the easiest way and should a minimal unwanted effect. If anybody has an opinon on this I would be interested to hear it.

items.title: Is there any documentation?

Hi,

is there any Documentation/Guide/Reference/HowTo etc. how to use the kiwi python bindings?

Thanks!

items.title: solver not always deterministic....
items.body:
We are using kiwi solver in Matplotlib for our constrained layout system.  It usually works great, though we can ocasionally be hit by #15  

Equally mysterious, is that very occasionally one of our complicated tests fails to find a good solution, doesn't give an error. I think we are OK with that outcome (optimization routines do not always find an optimal solution), but we were wondering if it is possible to make the outcome more deterministic?  Is there is a random starting point in the optimization routine, and maybe its possible to set a seed to a single value so that "random" point is the same for each test?  

Of course the fact that we get an un-optimal response sometimes possibly means the constraints have not been set up properly.  But its hard to know how to test for that and see where the logic is incorrect.    If we suggest values that are from a working solution will that allow it to optimize better?  

Thanks a lot for any suggestions.  

See https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/12683 and https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/12433

items.title: Failing test on Windows / Python 2.7 + 3.4
items.body:
Format of exponent in output string appears to be different from other platforms on Windows Python 2.7 and 3.4:

```
================================== FAILURES ===================================
__________________________ test_constraint_creation ___________________________
    def test_constraint_creation():
        """Test constraints creation and methods.
    
        """
        v = Variable('foo')
        c = Constraint(v + 1, '==')
    
        assert c.strength() == strength.required and c.op() == '=='
        e = c.expression()
        t = e.terms()
        assert (e.constant() == 1 and
                len(t) == 1 and t[0].variable() is v and t[0].coefficient() == 1)
    
>       assert str(c) == '1 * foo + 1 == 0 | strength = 1.001e+09'
E       AssertionError: assert '1 * foo + 1 ... = 1.001e+009' == '1 * foo + 1 =...h = 1.001e+09'
E         - 1 * foo + 1 == 0 | strength = 1.001e+009
E         ?                                       -
E         + 1 * foo + 1 == 0 | strength = 1.001e+09
..\kiwi\py\tests\test_constraint.py:25: AssertionError

```

* https://ci.appveyor.com/project/matthew-brett/kiwisolver-wheels/build/1.0.3
* https://ci.appveyor.com/project/matthew-brett/kiwisolver-wheels/build/1.0.3/job/1x37bdmbnsn17xq4#L132

Maybe worth a platform check in the test?

Thanks for the package.

@tacaswell pointed me here, to ask if I could help with building wheels, so we can use kiwi for Matplotlib.

I had a quick shot, but there is a problem I would like to ask your advice on:

I don't think it's possible to test an installed `kiwisolver`.  At least, when I try:

```
pip install .
mkdir tmp
cd tmp
py.test --pyargs kiwisolver
```

I get:

```
=============================================================== test session starts ===============================================================
platform darwin -- Python 3.5.1, pytest-3.4.0, py-1.5.2, pluggy-0.6.0

(no name '/Users/mb312/.virtualenvs/test3/lib/python3.5/site-packages/kiwisolver.cpython-35m-darwin.so' in any of [])
```

This is a killer for wheels, because we obviously want to make sure that the installed wheel is functioning correctly, before shipping.  Do you have any suggestions?

items.title: Naming
items.body: It seems that there is a name conflict with [kiwi on pypi](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/kiwi/9.6.2) would it be possible to resolve this?

items.title: Changing expression constant
items.body: Hello, what is the proper way to animate the constraint? With iOS/MacOS auto layout you would normally animate the constant of an already added constraint, but I can't see a proper way to do it with kiwi.

items.title: py27+kiwi doesn't like `from __future__ import unicode_literals`
items.body:
The following fails when using python 2.7 (works fine w/ python 3.6).

```python
from __future__ import unicode_literals

import kiwisolver as kiwi

Variable = kiwi.Variable
solver = kiwi.Solver()
top = Variable('boo')
```
with:

```
python testkiwi27.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "testkiwi27.py", line 7, in <module>
    top = Variable('boo')
TypeError: __new__() argument 1 must be string, not unicode
```

If I remove the `__future__` it works fine, but the project I'm working with uses the future, so I can't really remove it (matplotlib).  

I can cast all kiwi string arbuments to `String`,  but maybe its a better solution for kiwi to recognize Unicode or do the cast itself?

Other string arguments fail as well (i.e. the strength arguments).

Thanks!

items.title: STL containers are too slow in debug
items.body:
I have around 200 variables and 2000 constraints, this works ok in release (takes around 0.2s to add everything), but times in debug are ridiculous: around 7s. After profiling a bit, it looks like all the time is taken in STL/Loki stuff:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1333661/29709483-c7931748-898c-11e7-8d18-b1ef2fdb32de.png)

Would be nice to workaround it somehow, maybe using custom memory efficient containers? Or maybe add ability to prepare solver state in offline and just load it as-is in online without doing much work.

items.title: Can cassowary solve for modulo and modulus?
items.body:
So the two operations that would make a lot of constraints easier to model (some of which are impossible without) are modulo (`a % b`) and modulus (absolute value, or `|a|`). I know the absolute value one might be tricky API-wise since there's no operator for it, though `a == b.abs()` would be acceptable I would think.

Is this something the solver could actually solve? The operations are a bit much for me to comprehend without understanding cassowary at its core I feel like, or else I'd either 1) know the answer, or 2) submit a PR.

items.title: Sciter is using Kiwi
items.body:
Just let you know that [Sciter Engine](https://sciter.com/) is using Kiwi for some flow calculations. This style: ``` section { flow: grid(1 2, 3 3); ``` with this markup ```
1
2
3 (second row, spans two columns)
``` invokes kiwi constraint solver.

items.title: [kiwijs] Constraint C Strength affects the priority at which constraint A beats constraint B
items.body:
In this setup, there is initially one variable and two constraint. One Constraint (A) is an inequality, the other constraint (B) is an equality used to set a value on the variable. B can break A or not.

_priority_ is a strength created like this  : kiwi.Strength.create(0, 1, 0, _priority_).

```
A: variable >= 100 (priority 501)
B: variable = 90 (500)
```

After solving, the result is variable = 100 and is the expected result.

Now, if I add another equality constraint C with a very low priority ```variable = 50 (10)``` the variable value after solving is 90. It means that adding this constraint helps constraint B to break constraint A even if constraint B priority < A priority && C priority < A&B priority.

With the C constraint, the A priority needed to break constraint B  is equal to (B + C).

```
A: variable >= 100 (501)
B: variable = 90 (500)
C: variable = 10 (10)
``` 
```
=> variable == 90 (Not expected)
```

```
A: variable >= 100 (511)
B: variable = 90 (500)
C: variable = 10 (10)
``` 
```
=> variable == 100 (Expected)
```

I also tried to suggestValue(variable, 90) instead of using constraint B and got the same results.

It seems that a third constraint affects the priority at which a constraint beats another , even if this third constraint priority is lower than the two other constraints fighting.

Is this a bug or the regular behavior ?

Test here: https://runkit.com/cacaodev/kiwi-bug (Hit the green button to run the test).

items.title: unknown vars count
items.body:
hi,
thanks for great library, I am trying to use it for my gui layout and I'm stuck with simple problem: the position and size of my widgets are kiwi Variables, i don't know how many of them (widgets) there will be, but to calculate the proper layout  i need a constraint that deals with them all, for example i want to say that the sum of the widths of all widgets should be equal to the size of the parent widget, how can i do that?

i want' to write sth like that
solver.addConstraint( width0 + width1 + width2 + (...) == parentWidth);

cheers

items.title: New Release?
items.body: Python 3 support has been in the repository for a while thanks to @jwiggins, but there hasn't been a release which includes this.  It would be helpful if we could have such a release for downstream projects (particularly Enable and Chaco).

items.title: Constraint with higher priority don't have effect.
items.body:
```
from kiwisolver import Solver, Variable
s = Solver()
w = Variable('w')
s.addConstraint((w==1) | 1001)
s.addConstraint((w==2) | 1002)
s.addConstraint((w==3) | 1003)
s.addConstraint((w==4) | 1004)
s.updateVariables()
s.dump()
print('value of w:', w.value())
```

Output:

```
Objective
---------
4008 + 2002 * e3 + 2004 * e5 + 2002 * e6 + 4 * e7 + 2008 * e8

Tableau
-------
v1 | 3 + 1 * e6 + -1 * e7
e2 | 2 + 1 * e3 + 1 * e6 + -1 * e7
e4 | 1 + 1 * e5 + 1 * e6 + -1 * e7
e9 | 1 + -1 * e6 + 1 * e7 + 1 * e8

Infeasible
----------

Variables
---------
w = v1

Edit Variables
--------------

Constraints
-----------
1 * w + -4 == 0  | strength = 1004
1 * w + -3 == 0  | strength = 1003
1 * w + -2 == 0  | strength = 1002
1 * w + -1 == 0  | strength = 1001


('value of w:', 3.0)
```

The value of w should be 4.0.

items.title: License
items.body: Would you consider switching to MIT license? I love MIT for its simplicity.

items.title: Manual solve
items.body:
This is mostly an optimization issue, but in essence you sometimes know when say 10 variables will be edited at once, and there is no need to solve in between each.

An option to set AutoSolve = true/false would be preferable (like the original implementation), with a dedicated ManualSolve()-method.

items.title: No way to weight constraints of equal strength
items.body:
As far as I know, the default implementation of Cassowary allows for "weighting" constraints of equal strength. 
In short: If two constraints of equal strength existed and both can't be satisfied at once, the one with greater weight would be prioritized. 

Why has this been opted out?

items.title: I want to add a callback to Variable, so I can update widget's attribute effected.
items.body:
I can hack the source and add a callback function to `Variable` easily, but I want to here your opinion on this, is there a more proper way to do this.
I saw a `Context` in `Variable`, but it's not used. I wonder what's the purpose of `Context`.

items.title: Inconsistent state
items.body: On large LPs I have seen the kiwi solver return values that don't satisfy the constraints even though the problem is feasible. We then remain in such an inconsistent state after further changes of the constraints. Reseting the solver seems to solve the issue.

items.title: Providing a name for Variables should not be required
items.body: Since variable names are not used besides in the `dump` function.

items.title: Use of kiwi from within Jupyter and dump (Redirection of stderr)
items.body: Jupyter redirects stdout and `Solver.dump` writes to the real stdout... Would be more convenient if it simply returned a string, which would be displayed inline.

items.title: Use as a regular LP solver -> no API to forcibly set the objective.
items.body:
The only way I could find to specify the objective function for the LP was to have all the constraint strengths be equal to zero except one, which is made so that the corresponding slack variable is what I want to minimize (up to a constant).

Is there a more elegant way to do this?

items.title: kiwi produces different result compared with another cassowary implementations
items.body:
[cassowary-js](http://blog.jramsay.com.au/simplex-solver-using-cassowary-js/) [example](https://gist.github.com/jangko/5f6ee9546c60760b6226) tested with kiwi yields:

``` text
Profit: 800
Ale: 12
Beer: 28
Corn: 480
Hops: 160
Malt: 1190   <- ???
```

another cassowary implementations including [python](https://github.com/pybee/cassowary) and [C#](https://github.com/jozilla/Cassowary.net) produce:

``` text
Profit: 800
Ale: 12
Beer: 28
Corn: 480
Hops: 160
Malt: 980   <- OK
```

any idea what happened here?

items.title: Welcome to overconstrained.slack.com
items.body:
I hope you guys will join us on overconstrained.slack.com. Request an invite by sending a mail to hfossli@gmail.com or let me know on this thread. 

There we can discuss all things cassowary and friends. Peeps from The Grid, Rhea and Auto Layout for iOS is there.

items.title: variables map grows in size
items.body:
In dynamic environment, when constraints added and removed frequently, solver's variables map grows in size.  It is because variable never removed from map even if every constraint it is used in are removed.  Here is the code:

```
from kiwisolver import *

solver = Solver()
for i in range(10):
    v = Variable("var%d"%i)
    c = v == 100;
    solver.addConstraint(c)
    solver.removeConstraint(c)
solver.dump()
```

I expected no variables, but got:

```
Variables
---------
var0 = v1
var3 = v7
var7 = v15
var2 = v5
var9 = v19
var6 = v13
var8 = v17
var5 = v11
var1 = v3
var4 = v9
```

items.title: Stay constraints
items.body:
I came across this library yesterday, and I'm very impressed how much smaller and faster it is compared to the original implementation! One of the things I noticed is that there are no stay constraints. I always found them a bit of a nuisance, and if it is possible to remove them I'd like to do this as well for my own C++ Cassowary lib, [Rhea](https://github.com/Nocte-/rhea).

How did you redesign stay constraints? Are they implicit for all variables now?

items.title: no tag for version 0.1.3
items.body: I'm just wondering why there is no git tag for version 0.1.3, even though on PyPI kiwisolver 0.1.3 is available.

that are not within the EasyInstall build area, and has been aborted.

Any ideas why it's trying to access /tmp/ or how to fix?

```

with no luck.  Am I missing something?

items.title: required constraints of zero-size not handled correctly
items.body:
``` python
from kiwisolver import *


x1 = Variable('x1')
w1 = Variable('w1')
x2 = Variable('x2')
w2 = Variable('w2')
w = Variable('w')


cns = [
    w >= 0,
    x1 >= 0,
    x2 >= 0,
    w1 >= 0,
    w2 >= 0,

    x1 == 0.000,
    w1 == 0.000,

    x1 + w1 == x2,

    x2 + w2 == w,

]

solver = Solver()
for cn in cns:
    solver.addConstraint(cn)

solver.addEditVariable(w, strength.medium)

for value in (20,):
    solver.suggestValue(w, value)
    solver.updateVariables()
    print 'x1', x1.value()
    print 'w1', x1.value()
    print
    print 'x2', x2.value()
    print 'w2', w2.value()
    print
    print 'w', w.value()
```

results are incorrect:

```
x1 20.0
w1 20.0

x2 20.0
w2 0.0

w 20.0
```

change x1 and w1:

``` python
    x1 == 0.001,
    w1 == 0.001,
```

results are correct:

```
x1 0.001
w1 0.001

x2 0.002
w2 19.998

w 20.0
```
